body: I think that's captured in #471. (one of these is a duplicate of the other.)
I'm ok closing this one then.
I agree - in the scenario that raised this defect, we had no failed activations. I just wanted to mention that we need a complete picture with regard to `ActivationFeed` book-keeping.

despite the inconsistent platform-specific Go parsing of the input, it sounds like the root cause of this issue is that `base64` is generating the \n which results in a non-compliant JSON string value.

ok to close?

Can you provide an example?

```
> touch t.zip
> wsk action create t t.zip
error: Unable to parse action command arguments: creating an action from a .zip artifact requires specifying the action kind explicitly
```
strange. I am seeing this error now as well.

> pass all the required env-vars explicitly

I'm ok with this option as well. It looks like we have about 25 of these extra properties to be added according to [docker-compose env vars](https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk-devtools/blob/master/docker-compose/docker-whisk-controller.env)

Another thought: IIRC the plan is to move to Typesafe Config, when I assume that we would create a generic JSON config file with default values in it, and only overwrite values with ENV VARS.
So the solution to be explicit with ENV VARS might be a good option for Typesafe config as well.

@rabbah, I think functionality would be more unified across consumers of the controller by modifying the backend activation code. Otherwise, we'd have different behavior in CLI, the Node JS client, etc. In any event, the first commit only modifies the CLI. Second commit modifies the controller.
@csantanapr @mrutkows is there a standard practice for how to name the license file? i see other apache repos use `LICENSE`.
Looking into the failure.  There was a recent API GW change that may be part of the issue.
cc @mdeuser @rabbah
Perhaps this should stay pinned. We can't keep getting bit by this.
Perhaps.... unfortunately, pinning in our build does not guarantee the version of the deployed api gw in ys1 or yp.

Sigh. Good point. For the open source community at least that not a concern and we should not break master and prs. For the deployed hosted version I don't see a compromise: we need to get the full test suite integrated, or decouple things further so that the impact is limited.
I will need to coordinate updating the openwhisk-client-js and openwhisk serverless framework plugin when this is released.

Yep let's coordinate thru this issue 
I would will even start marking it deprecated today in client js today and removed a bit before we remove from here.
@csantanapr has pinned the gw dependency to recover a healthy build.

I have met the same issue, this may be curl header is not working while downloading oracle jre from oracle website.  You may try my patch which works for me:
```
diff --git a/common/scala/Dockerfile b/common/scala/Dockerfile
index 78ff867..d5fe34b 100644
--- a/common/scala/Dockerfile
+++ b/common/scala/Dockerfile
@@ -15,7 +15,7 @@ ENV JAVA_HOME /usr/lib/jvm/java-${VERSION}-oracle
 ENV JRE_HOME ${JAVA_HOME}/jre

 RUN curl --silent --location --retry 3 --cacert /etc/ssl/certs/GeoTrust_Global_CA.pem \
-  --header "Cookie: oraclelicense=accept-securebackup-cookie;" \
+  -b "oraclelicense=a" \
   http://download.oracle.com/otn-pub/java/jdk/"${VERSION}"u"${UPDATE}"-b"${BUILD}"/d54c1d3a095b4ff2b6607d096fa80163/server-jre-"${VERSION}"u"${UPDATE}"-linux-x64.tar.gz \
   | tar xz -C /tmp && \
   mkdir -p /usr/lib/jvm && mv /tmp/jdk1.${VERSION}.0_${UPDATE} "${JAVA_HOME}" && \
```
@csantanapr did this already.

Hi Rodric, I was pointed towards this issue by Kailash Peri as a result of a ticket I raised (#5377-13398691) relating to exceeding the size of a Docker environment for a Python action using Pandas (itself dependant on NumPy).  Happy to share any details or collaborate if you need any assistance.  

I believe your comment is referring to adding NumPy/Pandas to the list of packages which can be called without needing to create a Docker environment that includes the extra packages.  If so, then I wholeheartedly support this approach as it'd make OpenWhisk far more accessible to these very popular data science packages.

Many thanks,
James Johnson
(fellow IBMer posting on my personal GitHub account)
@adriancole I'd be interested to get your thoughts on whether Tracing should be used in Prod ( with sampling ) vs Non-Prod environments.
I think this issue can be closed as of: https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/commit/af6b00306f5060cf6abfca2a09ab91c482e8cc1a

Will deliver this in a separate PR that fixes other accounting issues with active acks.
same issue here. @Little-gg I manually made the changes you post, but it still doesn't work. Any suggestions would be much appreciated!

@Joranson try the following codes to check whether you can download java outside your container:
```
VERSION=8
UPDATE=131
BUILD=11
curl -L -b "oraclelicense=a" http://download.oracle.com/otn-pub/java/jdk/"${VERSION}"u"${UPDATE}"-b"${BUILD}"/d54c1d3a095b4ff2b6607d096fa80163/server-jre-"${VERSION}"u"${UPDATE}"-linux-x64.tar.gz -O
```
Check your curl output, and you may see the progress. If java is in downloading progress, that means that is the docker issue, not the curl issue.
Thank you for your reply @Little-gg
Try the fix suggested here: https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/issues/32
I suspect if your nginx is not up, then this is the reason you can't use the API host.

ant can't be used to build the current version I suppose. Used gradle as per the revised version. Steps to be followed are the same ? I cannot do it with ant as there is no build.xml file, so can you please tell how to fix this issue using gradle ?
Do you have /tmp/nginx owned by root?

Sorry for the delayed response. I think it was owned by root. But I deleted it while following some instructions to solve the above problem. Now I can't locate that file. And the problem is still not resolved. Please help.
run `wskdev edge` to redeploy nginx. You. An just recreate the directory (without root /tmp/nginx if necessary).
Thanks a lot. It works :+1:

```
ansible-playbook -i environments/<environment> invoker.yml
```

New host(IP) should be different with existing one.
Did you test with Docker-machine?
Use `-i` with your wsk commands.

vagrant@vagrant-ubuntu-trusty-64:~/openwhisk/bin$ ./wsk -i list
error: Unable to obtain the list of entities for namespace 'default': The connection failed, or timed out. (HTTP status code 502).

Still there is connection problem. Is it because I did not use any certificate ?

Hi Rodric/Carlos,

Seems there is agreement, do you guys have a ETA , i have a IBM project where the frontend is going to be in Ember and using Ember data and so this is a blocker for me.

Thanks,

Carlos Galveias
Please update the docs accordingly.

In addition we should look into reducing the amount of disk space consume by the nodejs runtime

- Using `--production` when running `npm install` will avoid installing `devDependencies`
- Going over the node_modules, and write a script to delete any test directories or installer directories
  For example if adding `ibm_db` it adds 80MB of installer code `node_modules/ibm_db/installer` not required for execution
- Have all the `RUN` statements in a single `RUN` encapsulated in a single script ~setup.sh
- Any others :-)
@jeremiaswerner This will not work take a look #2311
@csantanapr thanks for pointing me to the issue. Travis was failing due to that reason.
@csantanapr thanks. I agree. let's focus on fixing #2311 which would resolve this issue. Users could then leverage the .zip file support which would result in much smaller files. closing this PR.
I'd also consider an approach like the one intended for https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/issues/2300

>  The nodejs6action should have everything required for an user to use it to build a nodejs action zip.

Trying to grok your proposal... Do you mean some development-time mechanism (so that compiled binaries get uploaded with the action) or compilation at runtime or installation-time?
When I previously discussed this use case with @ddragosd and @sandeep-paliwal we thought that we would provide tooling that allows developers to compile to the right environment ("right" == "the targeted OW instance") and package the binary along with their NPMs (zip file)
@dubeejw would be this something you can handle?

Same issue with another command later on the tutorial:


```
D:\OpenWhisk>wsk action invoke --blocking --result packageAction --param lines '["and now", "for something completely", "different"]'
error: Invalid argument(s): for something completely,, different]'. An action name is required.
Run 'wsk --help' for usage.
```

Again, this worked fine when executed from the Git Bash shell, producing:

```
$ ./wsk action invoke --blocking --result packageAction --param lines '["and now", "for something completely", "different"]'
{
    "padded": [
        ".......................and now",
        "......for something completely",
        ".....................different"
    ]
}
```

I think the shell is interpreting the action name as a local directory/file path. 
Instead try using quotes "/whisk.system/utils/echo" so it gets interpreted as a string
@Little-gg Thanks! I believe it's a docker issue.

@csantanapr agree with not unilaterally adding ibm-specific library/service support if it is not being driven by the Apache community alongside other similar efforts and we establish a criteria for adding support for specific "drivers" that is part of our Apache process.  Where are the user requests coming in from and can we have some discussion of this on the dev list?

I tried your suggestions, but it did not help:

```
$ ./wsk action invoke "/whisk.system/utils/echo" -p message hello --blocking --result
error: Unable to invoke action 'C:/Git/whisk.system/utils/echo': The name of the
 entity contains illegal characters. (code 21582166)
Run 'wsk --help' for usage.
```

and also with single quotes:

```
$ ./wsk action invoke '/whisk.system/utils/echo' -p message hello --blocking --result
error: Unable to invoke action 'C:/Git/whisk.system/utils/echo': The name of the
 entity contains illegal characters. (code 21583022)
Run 'wsk --help' for usage.
```

```
$ ./wsk action invoke \/whisk.system\/utils\/echo -p message hello --blocking -
-result
error: Unable to invoke action 'C:/Git/whisk.system/utils/echo': The name of the
 entity contains illegal characters. (code 21706817)
Run 'wsk --help' for usage.
```
```
$ ./wsk action invoke //whisk.system//utils//echo -p message hello --blocking -
-result
error: '//whisk.system//utils//echo' is not a valid qualified name: A valid qual
ified name must be specified.
Run 'wsk --help' for usage.
```
```
$ ./wsk action invoke \whisk.system\utils\echo -p message hello --blocking --re
sult
error: Unable to invoke action 'whisk.systemutilsecho': The requested resource d
oes not exist. (code 21710430)
Run 'wsk --help' for usage.
```
```
$ ./wsk action invoke \\whisk.system\\utils\\echo -p message hello --blocking -
-result
error: Unable to invoke action '\whisk.system\utils\echo': The name of the entit
y contains illegal characters. (code 21711129)
Run 'wsk --help' for usage.
```
If wsk could accept the \ or the // as a separator, this last form could work in this shell on Windows. 

On the other hand, using this shell on Windows is rather unnatural, so fixing the issues that happen with cmd.exe may be the preferred choice.
@csantanapr what is the proposal? Two annotations: one for options and for methods to accept? I think we need to spell out exactly what we want the UX to be.
Can you try with `-v`: `wsk -i -v list`. Also consider joining http://slack.openwhisk.org (you're welcome to direct message me for help).


@csantanapr @mdeuser might you have some input to offer?

I'll guess this is related to #2313; did you try double quotes but escaping the nested ones?
https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/issues/1291 related.

Using external double quotes and escaping the internal double quotes works using cmd.exe on Windows:

```
D:\OpenWhisk>wsk action invoke --blocking --result packageAction --param lines "[\"and now\", \"for something completely\", \
"different\"]"
{
    "padded": [
        ".......................and now",
        "......for something completely",
        ".....................different"
    ]
}
```

#2313 is related to running the GIT Bash shell on Windows, not cmd.exe.
A few days ago our CI was also affected - we bumped the JDK version - is this still an issue if you're on master?
Since you opened another issue for the last comment I will close this one.
Duplicate of https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/issues/2304.

First, while you *can* run Windows executables from WSL, why are you doing so? Why not use the Linux binary instead? I'd consider (and to be clear, I do *not* speak for IBM here) using the Windows .exe in WSL as unsupported.

I would say that the user experience today is confusing. 
I read that I should use the GIT Bash shell on Windows. 
But when I logged into the BlueMix UI, it directly prompted me to download the CLI for Windows (based on my Browser user-agent?) 
That's how I came to try the above combination. If the intent is to make the Windows users utilize the Linux binaries with the Git Bash shell, then I think that the docs should point that out. 
But that also raises the question of why you would have the Windows CLI in the first place?
Oh my goodness, I apologize - I saw "Bash shell", not "Git Bash Shell"! I apologize!
To add more to my last comment, I'm on Windows, but I use the Windows Linux subsystem bash shell, hence me saying I'd use the *Linux* CLI for that and not the Windows one.
Thanks for the feedback @lziosi. I will open an issue against the UI in Bluemix to address.

I can definitely confirm this bug. However, if you use Powershell (and I assume cmd.exe), it works well. So it's either a bug in wsk.exe, or something wonky in Git Bash.

Hope this helps!
yes, this works for me in cmd.exe. It's just that the docs suggest to use Git Bash on Windows.
The Windows `wsk` CLI also works for me inside cygwin bash on Windows
Fair enough - @rabbah - could we quickly remove that from the docs for the time being?
@lziosi - Just to be sure we make the confusing doc pages are more clear, could you paste the link to the page describing the git bash shell requirement.  Thanks!

if i understand the original failure posting correctly, the installation of the local couchdb container image failed due to a network/connection issue with the registry hosting the couchdb image.  please retry the hello.cmd command again; if the network issue is temporary, the script should make further progress

Nothing to do with windows.

From the attached txt file 
It looks like this fails during pip install ansible 2.1.2.0

Please try again we upgraded ansible to 2.3.0.0 maybe this time will work

This brings a good point that I see, the script didn't stop at ansible break, it continues to next task, probably a good thing to add `set -e` on all this installation scripts for ubuntu so it stops at first error

>I read that I should use the GIT Bash shell on Windows.


The docs don't have this information, so far I have not found where you get this impression

For Windows users they should always download windows binaries:
They should use cmd.exe or powershell.
I tested latest windows build today and both seem to work.

I like to use Github Shell, which get's installed when you install the Github Windows App.
Github shell to my understanding runs on top of Windows Power Shell.
I also tested today with latest build.

I just tested Git-bash (https://git-for-windows.github.io/) which is different from Git Shell from Github. And it seems to have a problem with entities full qualified names like describe in the original comment on this Issue.
```
$ wsk action invoke /whisk.system/utils/echo -p hello windows
error: Unable to invoke action 'C:/Program Files/Git/whisk.system/utils/echo': The name of the entity contains illegal characters. (code 454638)
Run 'wsk --help' for usage.
```
I tested multiple combinations of trying to make this shell happy to take the string as type but is getting converted.
The git-bash is based on mingw and according to this http://www.mingw.org/wiki/Posix_path_conversion I should be able to type `//whisk.system\utils\echo` with no success.

You should not use the wsk linux binaries from cmd.exe, powershell, or git-bash if you do you should see the following error
```
 cannot execute binary file: Exec format error
```

As far of Bash on Ubuntu for Windows, I have not tried yet since my current Windows VM, is outdated, and out of space. So I will delegate to folks like @cfjedimaster to comment on how it get's setup and use.

One idea to workaround the issue with mingw interpretation on windows with shells like git-bash is to add a paramter to compose full qualified names like with an extra parameter to compose the entity name with an extra flag to specify the namespace

```
wsk action invoke --namespace whisk.system utils/echo -p hello windows
```
wsk on WSL (Windows Subsystem for Linux) works perfectly as far as I can tell. I no longer use wsk.exe.

@cfjedimaster

Extracted and then copy this to some place in your Linux Path? Like `/usr/local/bin/wsk`

@csantanapr it wasn't "setup" - I just got the binary, downloaded it, and put it in /usr/bin. I didn't extract anything. Basically just downloaded this: https://openwhisk.ng.bluemix.net/cli/go/download/linux/amd64/wsk
